thread.title: Roger shows off Australian Open trophy
thread.title_full: Roger Federer shows off Australian Open trophy | Daily Mail Online

author: Andy Warren For Mailonline
title: Roger shows off Australian Open trophy
text:
Roger Federer was on top of the world as he rolled back the years to win the Australian Open title in January, with the Swiss star taking his tennis to new heights.
Federer's victory over Rafa Nadal in Melbourne saw him earn a first Grand Slam title in nearly five years and ensured he picked up the 18th of his illustrious career.
The celebrations continue, with the 35-year-old now taking the famous trophy to the top of a snow-capped mountain to fulfil a personal ambition of his.
Roger Federer has shown off his Australian Open trophy on top of a snow-capped mountain
The Swiss star also attempted a serve on the mountain as he continues to celebrate his win
Federer insisted it has always been his ambition to scale new heights with a Grand Slam trophy
FEDERER'S SLAMS Australian Open: 2004, 2006, 2007, 2010, 2017
French Open: 2009
Wimbledon: 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2009, 2012
US Open: 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008
He even attempted a serve atop of the peak, before posting three images to mark the occasion on Instagram.
He captioned the images: 'Always wanted to take the trophy to the top of a mountain. From down under to up high.'
Following his victory, he returned home to a heroes welcome as he was mobbed by fans on his way through the airport in Zurich.
Speaking after the victory, Federer said: 'Tennis is a tough sport, there are no draws but if there were I would have been happy to share it with Rafa.
Federer beat old rival Rafa Nadal in Melbourne to claim his 18th Grand Slam title
It was the fifth Australian Open triumph of his career and his first Grand Slam since 2012
'When we saw each other four or five months ago (at Nadal's academy) we never believed we could be in the finals. I'm very happy for you, I would have been happy to lose.
'I work hard but try not to shout about it. It has been a different last six months and I wasn't sure I would make it here.'
